comments.commentBody:
If you think Japanese food is spicy, you haven't eaten Japanese food. Or haven't eaten it prepared properly.

Yes, wasabi will clear your nose, and shichimi (spice sometimes added to udon or soba noodles) can be spicy too. But normally, both are used in extreme moderation, and only when eating certain foods - sushi/sashimi or noodles.

Nearly all Japanese food is very delicately flavored - some might even call it bland, but certainly not spicy.
Hahaha, that seems like such a self-centered way of looking at the cuisines of other cultures.
More for the rest of us, I guess.

Long term effects of GMO's? You need to take some biology and genetics. I challenge you to stop eating everything that has not had its genes modified. And that goes for things where the genes were modified in a lab and those where the genes were modified on a farm.

As a liberal and progressive, I find the repetition of corporate babble-speak ideology in the face of facts to be about as stupid as Republican hatred of climate science. Please, oh please take some actual science so you can understand how evidence works.

Is Europe turning against science or against agribusiness and the scientists involved with it? Each agribusiness entity can be trusted at most to look after its own bottom line. Herbicide and insecticide makers would insist that their products are unrelated to colony collapse disorder because any relation would likely cost them money. If they needed evidence, they would pay handsomely for it and chances are it would appear.

European farmers and consumers are more protected from agribusiness than we are. Consumers get more complete product information, and farmers are not pushed towards a monoculture that would destroy centuries of history. Europe is content to let us be the guinea pigs for the long-term effects of G.M.O.s, and so, of course, is agribusiness.

.
I love singing along with that hymn (paean?), choosing different harmony lines as I see fit. I have to fudge the lyrics after "sed" tho. I'm guessing it all pretty much means "No glory to us, but all to God".

Anyway, Branagh's Hal/Henry dictates that Te Deums be sung, among other post-battle rituals. I didn't notice any *tedium* in the film, except maybe when Alice is teaching the princess English vocabulary.

Thou shalt hear Herald no more (until Sunday).

"I hope the Times will invite someone with strong credentials to write an opinion piece on the many reasons why the GMO approach poses dangers to our society, food supply and environment."...It will be very difficult to find someone with a solid scientific background who would do that. In fact a higher percentage of scientists support GMOs than support global warming. As a scientist it is very concerning to read so many posts from people who are scientifically illiterate. Genetics is a fascinating field, and you can't consider yourself to be an educated person if you don't understand the basics. The level of illiteracy shown here is truly depressing.

The argument against Daylight Savings Time in Japan is that it would create a longer work day. People can't leave the office until it gets dark, so a later sunset would mean longer hours (more zangyo,more karoushi). And since overtime is pay is not much more that regular pay, it is not a significant expense to the employer. Further, for the many employees who are not hourly employees, there is no overtime pay at all. So you wouldn't be playing catch in the back yard with your dad; he'd be in the office finishing up some project and you would be in a jyuku studying for your university entrance exam.

As a friend's father liked to sing
Do not waste those precious morning hours
With their wondrous golden showers
But arise and greet the sun
And everyone will say "Well done."

If you want to play catch with your dad, get up early and do it before breakfast.

I actually like the really early summer mornings in Japan, though that's a personal preference.  The real reason that Japan won't seriously consider DST is because it is associated with the Occupation after WW2, the only time that Japan had a national summer time.  In recent years, there have been some pushes to institute DST--most not very successful--and some more informal community time shifts in Hokkaido.

There's nothing wrong with France's time. If you are going to error, that's the way to error. I believe I suffer from SADS. I have no problem with a late sunrise, but an early sunset is massively depressing, and a late sunset is actually elating.

Last winter I attempted to spend my winter break in Malaga, in Southern Spain for no other reason than it has the latest sunset in the Winter in Europe. So, In my mind, there's nothing wrong with France's time zone. The real problem is they are too far north.

Now consider a real problem. Japan (and Korea). Japan is in two times zones too far east AND doesn't have daylights savings time at all. Dawn's twilight occurs between 3am and 4am. Sunset occurs at 7pm.

That's rediculuos.

Japan & Korea won't even consider going on daylights savings time. They should go one hour west and then go on daylights savings time.

My best memory growing up is the time I spent with my dad playing catch in the back yard after dinner between 6:30 and 8pm. You can't replace that time. You can take it away by moving dawn up to 4am in the summer.

If France has erred, at least it has erred in the right direction. I also have a great memory of sitting by the window over the long twilight in early July in a small town in Normandy.

If I was in France I would fight this measure you propose with all my strength.
This is a well-known, though less-frequently relied on, type of clueing from cryptics. More of a last resort for the constructor, being among the least clever types of clue.
I'm no Rubio fan (I'll support Hillary Clinton if she is the nominee), but really, criticizing him because he accidentally placed his water bottle too far away?
I've been so focused on Rubio's notorious money management record, I forgot all about his drinking problem.  Thanks for (en-) lightening my day, RR!

I don't think so, Rima, but I almost hope you're right. Actually nominating Trump would be the true death knell of the Republican Party. They would never live it down (and the minds of the evangelicals and the establishment would all go boom!).

Oh, Ross! Rubio? Really? Marco-I'm-So-Thirsty-I'll-Sneak-Water-And-No-One-Will -Notice, during his first State of the Union response?

That moment is still the first and only image his name conjures for me... You can see it here. http://www.rimaregas.com/2015/10/marcos-thirst-blog42/

You're right about Jeb! I don't even think he's done well enough to call his campaign flailing.

No, it won't be Marco. as much as you hate the idea, it'll be Trump. That's how bad it is.

Spend a little time and learn something. GMOs are popular with farmers precisely because they require less herbicide use not more. GMOs also require fewer passes over the field so less fuel is used as compared to conventional crops. GMO crops are significantly more eco friendly than conventional crops.

Unfortunately, Elizabeth I believe you will be disappointed in the personas the Herzlich's have previously used to portray themselves, see attached link, http://www.rightentertainment.com/?p=4073
I am disappointed in the NYT. The contrast of this article 's image with that of Mark Herzlich's past tweeted image and post begs questioning and reconciling.

Mark and Danielle Herzlich are the kind of player-family the NFL should support and praise at every opportunity. Their commitment to ending domestic abuse -- to the extent he discourages even joking and laughing about taking advantage of others -- is such a rarity. Our culture looks at the wounding of others as entertainment (witness our film industry) when it is actually the intentional infliction of pain on others; there is nothing entertaining or funny about it.

That Mark and Danielle found each other is fortunate for both of them, for they seem to complement each other well and play off each others' strengths. It is also fortunate for the many people who have survived domestic violence and who have been helped by their support of My Sisters' Place and their work with support groups. Their willingness to talk about domestic abuse makes it easier for others to do the same. It would be easy to say that it is behind them now and choose to move on, but they choose to connect and help people. To me, this is true caring.

"Besides, if G.M.O. is such a terrific idea, why the industry is against G.M.O. labeling?"....The implication of labeling is that something is dangerous. Concern about the safety of GMOs is not supported by scientific fact.  Be honest, the goal is to put a fraudulent burden on people who grow GMO crops. It makes more sense for people to label their products as non GMO if they want to, and no one is stopping them from doing so.
It seems this recipe is not only vegetarian but vegan.

I read the two Wikipedia pages on Drax. A massive attempt to replace 3 GW of coal burners by burning biomass from 12,000 square kilometers of sustainable tree farms, mistakenly called forests in the articles.

I still find that if all other values for trees as forests are ignored, the EU carbon dioxide rules closely correspond to reality.

But I would far rather see Drax replaced by several nuclear power plants.

The image of California as some kind of paradise has always been a something of a mirage. For the early settlers, the image shattered in 1862 when forty days and nights of rain turned the Central Valley into a lake 20 miles wide and 200 miles long. Residents of San Francisco got another wake up call in 1906 when an earthquake and fire destroyed large sections of their city. There are good reasons why California never supported large native American populations. Fires, droughts, floods, earthquakes, mudslides, tsunamis and volcanoes have always been a big part of the landscape. It has taken large feats of civil engineering, and many dams of concrete and steel in pristine mountain valleys, to make California a pleasant place to live.

Instead of whining about a forest fire spoiling his vacation Mr Duane should appreciate that fire is a part of the landscape and native plants are adapted to it. I recently did the same drive from Mono Lake and Lee Vining over Tioga pass to Yosemite. The day before I arrived the pass had been closed due to an early snow. Climbing up to Tioga pass through mountains dusted with snow and wreathed in cloud, I knew I was looking at one of the most spectacular landscapes in the United States. At a small lake close to the top I parked and got out to look at the view. An icy wind roared through the pass, and I though of what awesome things modern roads and cars and gasoline are. The landscape was beautiful, but also very harsh and unfriendly to man.

As somebody below pointed out, Hillary Clinton didn't play the victim on Thursday. I'm guessing Maureen Dowd had kind of a tough week. Webb and Chafee call it quits, Biden decides not to run, and Hillary Clinton ends up getting campaign donations from many people who had previously harbored serious misgivings about her. With Biden out, I guess Dowd's great Irish hope now is fellow Catholic University graduate Martin O'Malley--but his campaign is heading nowhere fast.
Maybe Rubio is burying his light under a bushel and a bushel and a bushel and a bushel and a bushel.....

No problem here with guck, although I've heard of gunk more often. I liked the Halloween additions to the names. Calliope is at a Comic-Con today, dressed as Batman. Her older sister Cassandra is the Joker. It looked from the photos like they were having fun.

Lack of primary care access is certainly a major issue the country faces, and a challenge to the supposed efficiency gains from Obamacare.  But let me ask: why did you go to an ER and not an urgent care?  6 weeks is too long to wait to have a medical concern evaluated, but not every concern is truly an emergency, and there are often other more efficient ways to access medical care.

I recently developed a sebaceous gland infection in a place I could not see well and get to.  The appointment I was given was three weeks out. It continued to grow and get worse. If pain becomes intolerable after 8PM the Urgent Cares are all closed and the ER is the only choice. Infection cleaned up and out, prescription for antibiotics issued, problem solved. Doctor's appointment canceled.

Since Obamacare came into play, I now have a 6 week waiting period to see a physician's assistant. I had a medical issue and couldn't get an appointment. Guess what? I had to use the emergency room for the first time in my life. So much for reducing ER visits. This Obamacare law is a disaster.
A thought experiment: If the federal government paid each and every adult an unconditional $1,500 each month, would it affect trafficking in the United States?
So.. capital controls or no capital controls? https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=JIk-86LH9yY

But there are not huge uncertain risks. That's an invention out of whole cloth. "A basic right to choose what satisfies you," when it's motivated by bad ideas, is nothing other than ignorance in nutrition.
Um, if the government bans one of the alternatives, there is no choice. And the decision wasn't made by consumers or scientists, but politicians.

"Why would anyone spend years developing genetically modified crops in the knowledge that they will most likely be outlawed by government fiat?"

That's the point, obviously.

"This decision of a majority of European countries to apparently ignore their own experts may undermine any claim to the moral high ground at the coming Paris talks on climate change."

On the contrary, and Mr. Lynas is just being deliberately obtuse here. On both genetically modified crops and climate change the Europeans are following the same basic principle: the principle of precaution. When there are huge, uncertain risks, it is better to act to prevent rather than to wait and see if problems develop.

European (and many American) consumers don't want G.M.O. food. For whatever reason, it is their right to have a food chain which satisfies them. Why does Mr. Lynas want to overthrow this basic right to choose?
KJ. Several review I've read mention that the The Grand Sophy is anti-Semetic. I know it was written along time ago but any thoughts on that? I have t read it and it sounds really good otherwise.

Notwithstanding Maureen's bad girl persona, with respect to your first point, the US was a necessary and major component to the military action on Libya and should have planned for and ensured that the vacuum we created be filled.  Instead, we walked away from the mess, not having learned the lesson of Iraq.  Whether that's on Hillary or on Obama, I don't know, but it is a stain on their administration.

While it's possible and even probable that Hillary made some mistakes around Libya, it's worth noting that 19 countries intervened in that country during the civil war. To lay the responsibility for that military action on Hillary, Amanda Power and Susan Rice, as if the were the three witches of Macbeth were egging on Obama and the Pentagon, seems like a stretch.

Hillary is the sort of politician that people project all sorts of stuff onto. While Hillary is far from perfect, it gets a little weird when Republicans and some people in the press, assume that there is something nefarious or wicked about her, as if her intentions weren't good.

The problem I have with Maureen's take on these events and others, is that she has difficulty seeing Hillary or even Obama who couldn't be more different from her, in anything other than a negative light. Whatever one thinks of Hillary, her fortitude in the face of sometimes abusive questioning was astounding. I didn't see a victim at all. Yes, she may have come across sometimes as barely tolerating the questions but for the most part they were inane at best, vicious at worst. If that had been me forced to endure an 11 hour committee hearing, I would have had a steady supply of martinis waiting for me in the break room and by 5:00p I would have been passed out on the floor.

I think Maureen thinks that she can't change her mind or soften her opinions about anyone. Once they get that black mark next to their name, that person is kaput.

Bernie is my candidate, too.

I think you might be interested in reading the ARB report on Benghazi. It explains why Ambassador Stevens and his team probably did not see his trip as unusually precarious - intelligence failures were so incredible they're almost unbelievable. Had the intelligence community done their job, this tragedy would probably have been averted.

Plenty of blame to go around, from the Secretary right on down the line but I found the CIA (nothing new there) to be particularly deficient.

http://www.state.gov/documents/organization/202446.pdf
